children.subject: Awesome thanks for the advice! I actually might major In physics as well, which is why I’m considering Ee117a and physics 7c. Would a 7c, 105, and 61b schedule along with a lower div humanity course be too overwhelming? I’ve heard 105 and 62b are quite time consuming.

61b is very time consuming yes (my suggestion is to go over your project plans with the TAs- they can save you many hours by helping your design so it works first time), as is 105 (~15hrs a week for labs/hw).  If this seems too much (probably is), I'd recommend 120 instead of 105 (about half the time-it's just problem sets); it's actually very applicable for physics & optics as well- for instance in quantum mechanics, states are often represented in momentum space, the Fourier transform of position space (the class is also pretty cool in general).
Ah ok thanks . That was the original plan but 120 and 61b conflict unfortunately:(

Ah damn.  In that case I think it's worth trying 61B, 105, 7c- you can always drop one if it gets too much.  Note though that if you do continue in physics, upper division physics classes have pretty difficult problem sets (10-20 hrs), so it may be worth discovering your limits early.  Regardless, go for it and don't underestimate yourself :)

@Rohit

Is there anything in particular one should do to prepare if they plan on taking 137A without 7C (asking for myself)? I'll have taken Physics 7AB and EE 105 and 130 (at the very least) by the time I get around to 137A, if that helps.

It may be useful to brush up on linear algebra (I actually learned linear algebra properly from QM- I had taken the old 20/40 series, and math 54 sucks lol).  But otherwise it's pretty much doable without 7c.  If you are interested, you can watch the Leonard Susskind lectures on youtube.

Are you considering a double major in Physics by any chance?  Because personally, I would take 105 instead of 7c (unless you want to be a physicist)- you can take 7c later (also, I found 7c not particularly interesting; if you want to see what quantum mechanics is about, I would suggest taking 137A right away- 7c just solves schrodinger's eqtn for various scenarios-not fun- without really going into the interesting physics, mainly because it doesn't assume a linear algebra background).   As for EE117, if you are considering double majoring in physics, it might be a good idea to take it simultaneously with Physics 110A (a physics req.), maybe in the future.  So in my opinion, unless you know already that you wish to work on Antennas or waveguides, I would suggest taking EE 105 and 120 as soon as possible first, to get a good general introduction of EE (after these two classes you can look at almost every EE course on the bulletin and actually know what each one is talking about- you can always take EE117 later).  And if you are an E/M person, look into taking 117 with physics 110A.  My opinion, after reflecting back :)

history.content:
hi,

ive taken physics 7b, ee16a, and ee16b. I’m wondering how difficult ee117a is compared to these classes. I’m contemplating taking either ee117a or ee105, but since I’m already taking 61b and 7c, I’m not sure how doable 105 is. Thanks!
history.subject: EE117A Workload
